5687431.transcript_text3:
Rebecca McClellan from Santander. Just a couple of questions, please. Firstly, can you confirm your CapEx project for the full year, please?

---

Yes, at this moment, the best estimate still remains that it will end up in SEK 9 billion to SEK 9.5 billion for the whole year.

---

Okay. And my second question, the incremental longer-term investment cost is still going to be between SEK 600 million and SEK 800 million, is that right?

---

That's right. That's correct.

---

First question was just on, why have markdowns decreased marginally when the sales were so strong? I just wondered if there have been any change in the commercial strategy over the quarter? And then secondly, can you talk about any improvements you're making to your delivery offer online? And in particular, any plans to introduce click and collect?

---

Yes, the first question, markdown levels, I think when we're talking about the markdown levels, we also have to -- to always not to have always a correlation. Good turnover doesn't have to mean always that the markdown levels fell down, because it's always on different markets, a question of salesmanship. We are always reacting on what's happening on the market and we are pretty happy with the markdown levels we have. And I think also the most important thing is that we have a good customer offering. And then that we work with the markdown, so also, it's a tactical tool on each market. So -- and this quarter, we ended up that they were more or less 20 basis points -- having 20 basis points less negative impact on gross margin compared to last year.

---

And regarding your second question, I think it was about free delivery and click and collect, is that right?

---

That's right, yes.

---

Right. Again, this is -- when it comes to e-commerce, it's -- we think it's important to talk about the total offering. So it's about the fashion, quality, price and of course, lead times, et cetera. And I mean, we do offer free delivery sometimes in campaigns, et cetera, but it's not a standard thing. And we also think it's important to say that free delivery mean someone has to pay for it, either it's the customer in terms of you're putting the price and it's a higher price or it's the investor who, at the end of the day, perhaps don't get any returns on his investment. But -- so I think it's, in many cases, we charge for delivery and that's straightforward. But again, it's the total offering that's important. When it comes to click and collect and lot of other features, of course, we'll look into that. But at the moment, we don't offer click and collect.

---

I wanted to ask about China. As you say, it's your most important expansion market. Sales there are growing very strongly, but not as strongly as the store count. Can you confirm, firstly, that the like-for-like stores are still growing sales. And secondly, can you talk about the dynamics as to why the total revenue base is not growing as quickly as the store count? Is it square meters and not as fast as store numbers? Or is it you're going into less productive space in perhaps cheaper locations?

---

Yes, I think we've touched upon this question many times before. And first of all, we explain very quickly, we can't just look at the numbers. Because none of the stores that you see in the -- have just opened and there is still not so much revenues in the numbers. And secondly, of course, we started initially in the largest cities like Hong Kong and Shanghai, and then we have, step-by-step, moved into second tiers, third tiers, fourth tiers, et cetera. So it's a combination of many factors. But sales are strong and developing very well.

---

And then also, yes, to your question about the like-for-like development. So we are happy with the like-for-like development in China. It's developing in a good rate.

---

Yes.

---

And if I can attempt some insight on your group-level for like-for-like. I appreciate you don't disclose those in absolute terms anymore. But has the contribution from new space and new online stores accelerated versus the first quarter? Or can we interpret that your constant FX acceleration in Q2 as being mainly about like-for-like?

---

It's -- I mean, the store contribution -- space contribution is more or less the same levels as last year.

---

Could you just talk about a bit about the shoe collection? I mean, you already offer shoes across the range. So what's different about this relaunched category?

---

It's a big investment even though it's not as big as the sport. But it's about broadening the range, and there's a lot of product development. So for example, in comfort and materials, et cetera. And there's a greater variety of product with many different types of models.

---

And would we expect then that there will be a broader price range on these shoes to accompany the...

---

That's right.

---

And is it similar to what you've been doing in other parts of the offer of kind of generally broadening the offer and, obviously in some cases, increasing price points along with a set of the premium lines?

---

Yes, but this is specifically on shoes. And we are -- as you said, we are -- we will have a wider price range and a lot wider collection so to speak. And initially, as I've said before, it's going to be in selected 9 countries and run 30 selected stores. And they will be displayed in clear areas, in menswear, in ladieswear, children, et cetera.

---

Yes, and also that even though we are spreading the price range, it's still very, very good value for money.

---

Sure. And just in terms of the China launch, I mean I know you've given us a considerable degree of disclosure about kind of one-off for development costs through the course of this year. But is China in itself, with the e-comm launch, going to be a kind of significantly lumpy element that we'd actually see in the P&L? Or is it just part and parcel?

---

It's part of the parcel, I would say.

---

And it's all being done in-house? Or are you going to be using any third parties in terms of distribution or websites or anything like that?

---

When it comes to distribution, we will be working with third parties, but the rest of it will be in-house.

---

So 2 questions for me, one at a time. So first question on your online launches. It seems that you have -- you accelerate now the amount of countries that you are launching on. Do you leverage existing infrastructure? Or is there some incremental investments associated with these launches that are worth mentioning?

---

Of course, we are capitalizing on existing infrastructure and the IT systems over there, but for each country, there's a lot of additional work to be done. We have to adapt. There's a lot of different payment systems, cards, et cetera, and also logistics. But we are ramping up a number of new countries, but in terms of sales, we already cover maybe 60%, 70% of the group revenues.

---

Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And the other question, on a big pickup in the admin expenses. And I know it's not a big part of your costs, but they did grow more than double what your stores grew. Any color there that you could give?

---

Yes, it's mostly related to the long-term investments, of course. And as we said, it's more or less in the same range, the amount that's in Q1. And half of it is on cost of goods sold, and the remaining part is in the operating expenses, and also most of them may be in the admin expenses. So that's main reason to the bump up in admin.

---

Okay, that's perfect. And if I may, if I -- on your COS stores, because you mentioned that you will open more stores this year than last year. But you've just opened 9 stores, and now should we expect an acceleration of store openings for COS in the second half?

---

Look, it's more -- we're going to open more in the second half than the first half for COS, yes.

---

It's Anne Critchlow from SG. My first question is about & Other Stories. You say in the statement that's now generating revenue, but I guess it's been generating revenue for some time ever since you opened the doors of the first store. Did you mean EBIT, they're making a contribution to profit?

---

No, it was more -- it, of course, we are -- generating nice revenues increase.

---

Okay. And is it making a positive contribution to profit now?

---

We don't comment on positivity per cons and pros. We are happy with the development, absolutely.

---

Okay. Then the second question concerns your southern hemisphere sales. You've got quite a few areas now. So I'm wondering if your experience of what sells there is helping you to -- is helping inform you of trends that might sell in Europe 6 months later?

---

I don't think it's that simple. But of course, having both online and sales in the southern hemisphere helps us to get a better picture of how fashion moves and changes, absolutely.

---

It's Jamie Merriman from Bernstein. My question is about the sustainability initiatives that you've been working on and some of your comments about rising manufacturing wages that you're seeing in Asia. Can you give us some indication about the level at which you're experiencing that increase and also just philosophically, as your view that customers are understanding of that and willing to pay a bit more for a product that's more sustainable?

---

Yes, I'm glad you noticed that, for us, sustainability is very, very important. We take this very seriously. But when it comes to salaries, one example is, of course, in Bangladesh, where minimum salaries were up 78% as of 1st of December. And of course, this is reflected in the cost, that's what we say with increased salaries, cost inflation among the suppliers. And of course, that's part of -- we have to pay that. But we also see positive things coming out of it. We see that in the long term, it leads to better stability and better quality and less unrest, so it's a very good thing. First of all, of course, sustainability is good for the people and the environment. So there was a salary -- what was the second questions, please?

---

It was just about, are you seeing indications from customers that they understand your work on sustainability and are willing to absorb some of that cost?

---

Yes. We see, definitely, that this is not a short term. This is something that's becoming more and more important, and we see that more and more customers are asking for it. We also see that our -- when we look for employees, they want to work with a good company, so it's very important to have such in that perspective as well. And also for us to work within the company, I mean, we want to be proud of what we do and I'm very proud of what my colleagues in the company does. And just to add one more thing, when it comes to these increased cost for this some -- the suppliers, we don't -- we've decided not to pass that on to the consumers. That's part of the reflection in the -- that's reflected in the gross margin.

---

Can you please comment on the H&M Sport collection, how it's been -- how well it's been received and how many stores it's being expanded into? And then any updates on raw material prices, cost inflation in currency, and the outlook for their impact on the gross margin?

---

One question at a time. First question Sports had been very well-received, we're very happy. And so far, we have the extended range in around 50 stores. And we have a number of stores with the Sport and, generally, a number of stores, around 2,000 stores with Ladies Sports, et cetera. And we have now decided to expand this going further as a result of the very good reception. Your second question was about trying to quantify the increased cost in -- it's very difficult for us to quantify it. So that's why we say it's increasing, but it's difficult to quantify.

---

Just when you mentioned the long-term incremental investments for this year, should we expect that going forward also?

---

For this year, we have quantified it around SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million. Regarding next year, they will continue. But we will have to come back about the level, whether it's going to be increasing it further or decrease, but let's come back to that later on.

---

A question on online, please. In your big existing online markets, what proportion of the overall H&M range is actually available online for markets like U.K., U.S., Germany? And how quickly do you expect to close that gap as it were?

---

We are, in many countries, actually, we have -- we offer most products both online and offline, but I don't think the target is to be 100. Some products will be available only online and some products only offline. So this is a case-by-case. But it's -- you could say that most products now are available in both channels.

---

And the second, very anoraky [ph] one. How big is the store in Melbourne?

---

It's around 5,000 square meters.

---

Just going back to your comments on supply chain and sustainability and minimum wage increases. Just looking at it from the customers' perspective. What do your surveys show about whether people actually care about it and whether they're changing their shopping habits? I'm just trying to gauge whether we're right at the start of you getting benefit from it or you're already seeing that come through in shopping habits?

---

Yes, more and more people are asking for it, and it's becoming more and more important, and of course, we want to be proactive.

---

That's showing up in all your survey work?

---

Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. This morning, we reported our financial results for the first quarter of fiscal 2015. And we are pleased with the solid growth in sales and earnings, given the challenging weather, conditions experienced across Canada this past winter and early spring. 
I will briefly go over the sales and store expansion highlights for the first quarter before turning it over to Michael, who will provide you with a more detailed update on our financial results and key operating initiatives.
In this quarter, our sales increased by 11.8%, primarily driven by the expansion of the store network and continued organic sales growth. During the quarter, we opened 25 net new stores compared with 21 net new stores opened in Q1 last year. Our total store count across Canada is now 899 stores compared with 806 stores as of May 5, 2013. For fiscal 2015, we still expect to open between 70 and 80 net new stores with most of those stores located in Ontario and Western Canada, which are markets that continue to be under-penetrated with dollar stores. 
In this quarter, we also achieved a 3.3% increase in same-store sales through an increase in the average basket size while the number of transactions were slightly down, a decrease primarily attributable to the poor weather conditions in February and March.
From a merchandising point of view, our Easter sales were very good and the customers responded positively to our merchandise mix. Our focus now is on our summer season, which was delayed by the colder weather conditions this spring. Sales of summer seasonable items are now accelerating as the weather is warming up.
I would like to welcome, at this point, Johanne Choinière to the Dollarama management team. Johanne joined us as Chief Operating Officer effective May 12. She brings with her a wealth of leadership experience in the retail business, and she's already very involved in the day-to-day operations. I am confident that Johanne will contribute on -- to the ongoing growth and development of our business.
Michael, over to you.

---

As Larry mentioned, the increase in sales was fueled by the opening of 93 net new stores over the past 12 months and a same-store sales increase of 3.3%. We expect this trend to continue as we target a gross margin for the full fiscal year 2015 in the range of 36% to 37%, in order to stimulate continuous sales growth.

Overall, we still expect a slight improvement in the G&A ratio for the full fiscal year 2015 compared to fiscal 2014. In Q1, our EBITDA grew 13% to $86.2 million or 17.2% of sales.

As a result of the review of leasehold improvements and store and warehouse equipment effective February 3, 2014, we increased the estimated useful lives of substantially all of the leasehold improvements and store and warehouse equipment. 
Leasehold improvements are now depreciated on a straight-line basis over a period of approximately 15 years. So it's moved from 10 years to 15 years, which is consistent with the term of the lease, including one 5-year renewal option. Store and warehouse equipment is now depreciated on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of each asset, which now ranges from 10 years to 15 years. The effect of these changes was a decrease of approximately $4 million in depreciation expense for the 13-week period ended May 4, 2014. These changes reflect our current reality whereby the change in estimated depreciation rates match the economic life of those assets. 
And if I may, I'd get out of the script for 2 seconds. This $4 million, which applies to Q1, will also apply in Q2, Q3 and Q4. In other words, you will see the same impact. And this change was driven mainly by the increase in number of leases extending into the first renewal option.
So back into the script now. Q1 net earnings increased to $53.2 million or $0.78 per diluted share compared to $45.6 million or $0.62 per diluted share in the first quarter of fiscal 2014. The EPS this quarter would have been $0.74 per share if we exclude the $0.04 positive impact of the change in accounting estimate. Cash flows from operations increased to $18 million in Q1 from $13 million in the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal year.
During the month of May, we modified our capital structure by issuing floating rate senior unsecured notes in the aggregate principal amount of $150 million maturing in May 2017. The net proceeds of the offering have been used to repay indebtedness outstanding under the revolving credit facility. The offering has allowed us to lock in, for a period of 3 years, a favorable interest rate spreads of 0.54% over that 3-month VAs, which is much lower than our current spread over VAs on the revolving facility.
During the quarter, we repurchased for cancellation a total of 1.8 million shares for a total cash consideration of $154 million. During the period following the quarter, following May 4, 2014, until June 11, which is yesterday, we repurchased an additional 800,000 shares for a total cash consideration of $74.6 million. Therefore, since the launch of June 17 last year, 2013, of the 2013-2014 NCIB, and through June 11, 2014, we have bought back a total of 6.3 million shares, which represents 9.4% of the corporation's public float, at a weighted average price of $82.45 per share for a total cash consideration of $521.6 million. This morning, we also announced that we will be renewing our normal course issuer bid program, which will allow the purchase for cancellation of up to 3.5% of outstanding shares at June 11, 2014, over the period from June 17, 2014, to June 16, 2015.
Now let me give you an update with regards to our productivity initiatives. Compared to last year, we have reduced the number of manual daily counts at store level and increased our reliance on scan data for replenishment purposes. We completed the rollout of Kronos advanced scheduling functionally in all of our stores. The Kronos solution is used to manage time and attendance, as well as labor scheduling in our stores and warehouses. In fiscal 2015, we will continue benefiting from improved labor allocations brought forward by this initiative. 
Over the next few months, we will be taking advantage of some features of the new point-of-sale terminals rolled out to all of our stores last fall as we begin to implement new cash management procedures to improve efficiency of store processes.
Overall, we are very pleased with the financial and operating performance of the company this quarter and the progress made on our key initiatives that will support profitable growth in the future.
This ends our formal remarks and we can now take questions.
Operator, I'll turn it -- I'll turn the call over to you.

And then just on the 1,200 stores you anticipate for Canada, this is obviously a difficult thing to estimate. But what is your parameter for doing that? Yes. Sorry, go ahead.

And so where would they be now in terms of the number of stores.

---

The numbers? No, we don't disclose. Keith, as we said before, it's immaterial. We still have a ways to go. So to date, as Larry said, it's going well. So we're continuing with the project.

---

Yes. It's a small country, Keith. So if you had 15 stores when we started, you'd be opening a few stores every year. And it's more a learning experience than it is measuring how many stores they can open in a certain period of time. We've learned a lot by that experience.

---

---

We have no views on entering the U.S. market.

---

That's a tough market. Personally, I've always said that, competitively, it's a tough market to get into. And we haven't taken it any further than that honestly. We liked the challenge of the Latin American countries. We think there's more opportunity there than getting involved in that jungle in the States. So my view is kind of negative at the moment. Doesn't mean it's -- it will be permanently negative. Things change. But at the moment, it's not positive that we're going to get involved in that market. Again, we prefer the opportunities in the Latin American countries.

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
I want to dive into the gross margins a bit. The first quarter last year had a gross margin decline as well. ---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay. So -- well as we've stated this year, we anticipate -- we're managing down the margin to secure the top line and stimulate it as much as possible. Obviously, factors that have been impacting negatively, as we mentioned on the last call, you have -- I mean, the one that stands out is the currency. So -- and -- but as we also mentioned, even if the currency would not have impacted as much, we are clearly working the margin down into our -- the 36% to 37% range.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And on the same-store sales number, and particularly the traffic decline, how is traffic exiting the quarter and what are the various factors that might influence your traffic numbers over the remainder of the year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, clearly, we've seen in Q4 and again in Q1 and the traffic -- as I -- we mentioned on the last call, to February and March, we had very poor weather conditions. We're glad to see that the last month that we had nicer weather, so that's been definitely helping out. But clearly, the traffic decline, as it was in Q4, is associated to the poor weather conditions. So, that being out of the way, you should hopefully see traffic coming more into line.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. We -- it's -- Perry, it's Larry. We seem to see that traffic is really dependent on weather. And people -- if they can't get out of their house, they're not walking over to Dollarama to spend $5 to $10. They may go buy a snowblower at Canadian Tire. But in our case, we need -- not favorable weather, at least not very negative weather and it impacts our traffic. No question. The question -- also, just to add a little bit more color to your former question. I think moving forward, we're -- we'll be looking at some headwinds with respect to gross profits. I think one of them would be the foreign exchange -- negative foreign exchange. Another would be the higher occupancy costs, which continue to not be on our side and continue to climb. Another one, which a lot of people may not be aware of, is China has lost its favored nation status, which, in effect, means that duties on many products will be increased. In other words, I'll give you a few examples, we never paid duty on porcelain, anything we bought in porcelain, porcelain mugs, porcelain plates, et cetera. They're going up from 0% to 7% as a result of this. Other nations have also lost their favorite nation status, but the one that affects us is China. So these are negative headwinds. Plus competitively, we...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
January.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Sorry?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Just mention.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
That's kicking in January. The favored nation business is kicking in, in January. So today, we're buying with that in mind. The products we're buying for next year that we have to pay for it next year, we're keeping these increased costs in mind. So if we -- to pass them on to our customers is easily -- easier said than done, and we have to be very careful when we're doing that. So let's keep all this in mind when we're talking about decreasing our margins from between 36% and 37%.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
In your opening remarks, you noted that you had bought back just in excess of 9% of the shares outstanding. It -- under the prior NCIB. So I was wondering if you could walk us through the thinking behind renewing at that 3.5% level.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay. If I heard you correctly, Irene, the -- so this past year, we had a target of 10%, a 5% increase to 10%. And so we've used up most of the leverage capacity that we have within the investment grade zone. So in other words, to keep our BBB stable rating so we not only use the cash flow generated from operations but -- which was -- and that -- the close to $200 million last year, but also the additional leverage we had to buy back shares. Now that we have attained more or less the -- we're not at the maximum, but we're close to the maximum. We don't have, for the short term, any more leverage capacity. That leverage capacity will build over time as we get more EBITDA in -- record more of the EBITDA. So therefore, what's left is the cash flow generated from operation this year to finance that share buyback. So for the time being, we're going with 3.5% of the -- as a target. And if we get more momentum down the road, then we will look at increasing it if we need to.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
That's great, and that's very helpful. Also, just looking at the debit penetration in the quarter at 42%, you're getting closer to that 45-ish level that seems to be kind of the norm for Canada. And wondering whether you had any updated thoughts around the credit card piece.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, we don't have any new information on the credit -- I mean, debit is -- it continues to move up. It doesn't cost us anything. And right now, we feel comfortable. We'll see if that 45-ish estimated Canadian average holds for us, too. But for the time being, there's no -- nothing going on, on the credit card side.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
And just one final one, if I may. I'm just wondering about the maturation process of the higher price point. What we saw in the past was the buyers getting better and better at anticipating sell-through and consumer demand. ---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
It's Larry, Irene. We're seeing the same kind of thing, at the $2.50 and $3 level. Not yet, but I could see ourselves having that feeling. I don't know how shortly, whether it will be in 6 months, 1 year, 2 years. But I can see eventually that if you're talking about a certain amount of anxiety or a certain amount of feeling that we shouldn't be moving that price point. Is that where you're going with that question?

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
I think it was more around anticipating consumer demand and sell-through for the types of products at the higher price point and getting better at buying them, basically.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. We're -- I think we're getting better at buying the $2.50 and $3. I think there's more comfort there, and that's all I could say on that particular issue. So I think we're getting better, but that doesn't mean that -- I think where our suppliers are also showing us more at those price points, so not only -- it's -- this is a 2-way street between supplier and buying. I hope that answers your question.

---

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
I just had a question on your new stores and the ramp-up period to get them -- to get the sales to where you have with your existing store base and the payback. Are we still talking sort of in the 18 months to 24 months range?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, that's what we -- we're aiming for, absolutely, in terms of quality of real estate. We're going to -- it's going to be -- as I said on the last call, I believe the F '14 cohort will have a bit of a challenge because of the slower Q4 sales, which was our bigger season. ---

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
Okay. So I mean, if we were to normalize for weather, you're still sort of in that range, that 18 to 24 month.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I would say closer to 24. It's becoming more challenging. It's not becoming easier, the amount of infills we're doing. So if I was to throw you out a number, I'd like you to use more towards the 24, certainly, than the 18.

---

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
Okay, great. That's very helpful. And then just on your overall store target for Canada, is it -- are we still in that 1,200 range or are you seeing opportunities to open more than that over time?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, that's still our number.

---

【質問: Vishal Shreedhar (Analysts)】
Just given the change in the D&A policy, is there a change in your longer-term view on EBIT margin potential, that 17-ish percent?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes -- no, absolutely. So that follows through.

---

【質問: Vishal Shreedhar (Analysts)】
So sorry, there is a change then or...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. I mean, we were saying -- we were hoping to keep it around 17%, but that was before the adjustment. So -- but I mean it's not, well, way over. It's still in that range though. But it -- yes.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
So in the quarter, obviously, great expense leverage still. A little bit early for us to say that the Ontario wage increase is wholesomely reflected. So with the 60-plus basis point win on the expense rate, would you view that as sort of the expense rate gain that you can get without the wage increase there, or was there something extraordinary in the quarter that would've caused that rate benefit to be larger than what you would expect?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. There's the bit of the store acceleration we had in Q1 last year, and so there's a bit of timing there. So that's why I'm coming back and cautioning everyone not to model 60 bps per quarter here, but that's why I maintained my slightly improved yearly fiscal '15 G&A ratio. But we're hopefully -- we're hoping to slightly improve the G&A year-over-year for fiscal '15.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Okay. On the FX impact on cost of goods sold, plus now the favored nation issue, I just want some indication. Like do you -- when do you feel that the FX impact on COGS will be largely fully reflected in your cost of goods sold? Is it sort of by second or is it by third quarter?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
It would be more towards the fourth quarter that you could see that.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Fourth quarter, yes.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
And as part of the way of sort of managing it, we were talking about the $2.50 and $3 items. Do you feel that you have an opportunity to take some of your existing items up into those price points, or are you still a little cautious in terms of how you want to deal with that $2.50, $3 price point range?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, if you're talking about taking a $2 item to $2.50, it's a big jump. And then taking that $2.50 up to $3 is just as big a jump. So we are cautious as we are in every other price point. It's -- so it's a matter of balancing value and being competitive and timing. So it's to be seen. We're going to play a lot of this stuff by ear and slowly monitoring this whole situation. It's a new situation for us, and having negative FX and having a tough retail environment is not necessarily on my wish list. But...

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Obviously. Do you foresee in a reasonable timeframe, whatever that's supposed to mean, toying around with price points above the $3 level, or do you feel that's sort of on a normalized horizon, that $3...

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
You're going to have to define reasonable timeframe.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Well, obviously, if I was talking 10 years out and we had 3% inflation every year, $3 will become higher than $3. But within a 2-year timeframe, let's say, just for tangibility.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
That's really hard to predict. It's really hard to predict that, and I wouldn't even want to go there. We'll try and last at these price points as long as we can. And I can't predict -- I really...

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
It does sound, though, like on this $2.50 and $3 range, where, at one point in time, you were expressing some concern about the amount of items you could see that you could bring into those price points that that's gotten a little bit better. I don't want to overstate it, but...

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, it has. I think we're being offered more and more of those pricing changes, and the foreign exchange is helping us -- push us up there a little sooner than we would have wanted. I think I could leave it at that.

---

【質問: Patricia Baker (Analysts)】
Michael, just a small clarification on the accounting change with respect to depreciation. Was there some threshold level that you were looking at in terms of option, the renewals? Can you tell us like how many? What percentage of your stores you've done the 5-year renewal on?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No. In the one that weren't finished being amortized is the majority.

---

【質問: Patricia Baker (Analysts)】
Okay, that's good. And then secondly, just looking forward, and you both referenced the fact that we've had a slow start to the summer, this won't be the first time in your history that you've had a slow start to the summer. Can you talk about the summer season and, typically, what you experience when there is a slow start? Is there ability to catch up? Is it different than other seasonal periods during the year?

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
It depends how long it lasts. If it lasts until June, the catch-up is negligible. I think we got a break in weather a couple of weeks ago, and it's at -- if I may use an unorthodox word, I think it's catch-uppable at this point. And it's -- that's happening. If it happens, if the weather -- the miserable weather continues into the middle of June, we got the bigger problem and we're going to have carryovers as a result. Thankfully, our carryover is not ice cream, and the carryover are always -- is good merchandise that's bought -- can be kept for next year. It's not something we want. But again, I think we're doing a good job right now as long as it stops raining outside of Montréal here and we get some sun, that we can continue this catch-up very easily.

---

【質問: Patricia Baker (Analysts)】
Larry, that's useful. And then a third question, just around the higher occupancy costs. And the increased rent that you're seeing, is that related to just higher rents overall, or does it really relate primarily to going into more downtown locations where, obviously, rents would obviously be higher in any case?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I think it's both. I think, overall, rents are higher, although it seems to have leveled off. But it just can't continue going higher and higher. And the fact that if we want to go into the GTA or into downtown Vancouver, downtown Montréal, downtown Toronto, Calgary, it's more expensive. We're trying to control the size of the stores a little better that we go down -- that we go into, which means it creates logistical problems. ---

【質問: Patricia Baker (Analysts)】
Okay, all right. And then lastly, if I may, and hopefully I can sort of phrase this question in a way that you understand what I'm getting at. And at the end of the day, it really does come to a gap between the value perceived at Dollarama versus the valued -- for the -- a like product in a competitor. And there have been points in time where you've laid it out for us that the perception is that for a $1 item at Dollarama's is believed they'd be paying X times more at Walmart or somewhere else and the same thing with the 2. ---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I guess we have one word for that, absolutely.

---

【質問: Patricia Baker (Analysts)】
Okay. Would you want to elaborate or that's -- that just nails it?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I can elaborate on the word absolutely, but I think that does it. It's -- yes, we always want to maintain a certain gap in value. I think that's the idea.

【質問: Emily Foo (Analysts)】
So just going back to the question about maintaining the compelling value to customers. ---

【質問: Emily Foo (Analysts)】
Okay. And just a follow-up question for the decreased depreciation. So can we assume that the Q1 number to be representative going forward for the current amount of stores plus the new stores that comes up?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Right. By -- I mean, just for this year, it's approximately the same. So you can now assume $4 million per quarter.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
Yes. I was wondering if you know roughly the percentage of your products from China that will be subject to a tariff.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
No, I don't. And I'm answering that very quickly because I really don't. We haven't concentrated too much on working those numbers. I know some categories. But to say that 80% or 60% or 50% or 40%, those are numbers that have neither been provided to me nor -- maybe they should be, eventually. But I think it's category by...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
We wouldn't disclose that, Larry, anyway.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
We're not going to tell you anyway, Keith. So the answer is no, Keith. I don't know.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
Okay. And then just on the products that are priced at $2.50 and $3, how does the turnover rate of those products compare to products at $1, for example?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, it's -- we don't -- Keith, we don't disclose that detail of information.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I don't think -- I don't even know if we have.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, we have a lot of the information. But -- we have all of that, but we don't disclose it. So -- for obviously...

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And then just on the 1,200 stores you anticipate for Canada, this is obviously a difficult thing to estimate. But what is your parameter for doing that? Is it sort of one store per 30,000 people, or do you have sort of done it market by market? Or how do you come -- arrive at that just conceptually?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
So personally, I don't like that number of 1,200 stores, and I don't like using it. But since we are, you're asking how do we get there?

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
Right.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. No -- yes. So what we did is we work with an application called Tactician One. We have a group of consultants that map out the country by population size, density, retail activity. And we factor in competition, other dollar stores, Walmarts, Targets. And then we -- and we profile the areas, then we -- so that's how we estimate the 1,200 stores.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
So, Keith, all that said, Dollar Tree estimates opening 800 to 1,000 stores. What do you want me to tell you? If you want to get stuck on 1,200 -- I don't like using any number, because I've always underestimated the amount of stores we can put into a certain area. So I think that's a very conservative number. There's no -- there hasn't been a science into establishing that number, okay. But then you ought to ask Dollar Tree how they get to 800 to 1,000 stores and what science they used. So I'm a little -- I don't like using those numbers. As opportunities arise, we'll just keep going. It may end up being 1,200, 1,300, 1,400, 1,500. I don't know, Keith.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And then I'm just wondering if you could update us on -- and I know it's very small at this point, but on the progress in Latin America or Central America, I guess it is.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, this morning at the AGM, we kind of said we like the progress there. By progress, I mean the -- I like their sales reports that we're getting as a result of the fact of the direction we've given them. I like the fact that they're opening stores, not quite at the rate we are, but proportionally so. And I think the experience down there is a positive one so far. We're learning a lot about international business, and I think it's been positive in every respect.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes. Sorry, go ahead.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And so where would they be now in terms of the number of stores.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
The numbers? No, we don't disclose. Keith, as we said before, it's immaterial. We still have a ways to go. So to date, as Larry said, it's going well. So we're continuing with the project.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. It's a small country, Keith. So if you had 15 stores when we started, you'd be opening a few stores every year. And it's more a learning experience than it is measuring how many stores they can open in a certain period of time. We've learned a lot by that experience.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And just wondering, if I might ask, what your view is on entering the U.S. market.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
We have no views on entering the U.S. market.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
That's a tough market. Personally, I've always said that, competitively, it's a tough market to get into. And we haven't taken it any further than that honestly. We liked the challenge of the Latin American countries. We think there's more opportunity there than getting involved in that jungle in the States. So my view is kind of negative at the moment. Doesn't mean it's -- it will be permanently negative. Things change. But at the moment, it's not positive that we're going to get involved in that market. Again, we prefer the opportunities in the Latin American countries.

Thank you, Rick, and good morning, everyone. Rick covered the highlights of our first quarter sales performance, so I'll share more details on the rest of the results, starting with gross profit. Gross profit increased 5% for the quarter with a 57 basis point decrease in gross profit rate to 30.0% of sales. This decrease was primarily driven by the higher mix of lower-margin consumables, which includes tobacco and perishables. In addition, we incurred higher markdowns primarily due to promotional activities in consumables, which were partially offset by better initial markups. 
SG&A expense increased 9% to $978 million or 21.6% of sales, an increase of 37 basis points over the 2013 period. The impact of lower sales growth affected our ability to leverage our fixed costs, with rent and utilities having the most significant impact. Adverse weather also contributed to higher utility cost. As we called out in the fourth quarter, SG&A in 2014 is impacted by the sale-leaseback transaction, adding about 5 basis points in the first quarter. Decreases in workers' compensation and general liability expenses partially offset the overall increase in SG&A as a percentage of sales. 
As of May 2, total merchandise inventories were $2.6 billion, up 1% on a per-store basis. Over the last 5 quarters, we've made great progress in managing our inventory growth to be in line with sales growth. We are very pleased with our performance here. 
We generated cash from operations of $251 million in the quarter. Capital expenditures for the quarter totaled $84 million, including $27 million for improvements, upgrades, remodels and relocations of existing stores; $25 million related to new leased stores; $14 million for information systems upgrades and technology-related projects; $12 million for distribution and transportation; and $6 million for stores we built. 
Regarding our share repurchase program, as Rick mentioned, we repurchased 14.1 million shares for $800 million in the first quarter. Since the inception of the share repurchase program in December 2011, we've repurchased 44.5 million shares, with a total return of cash to shareholders of $2.3 billion. We currently have a remaining authorization of $223 million. 
Turning now to guidance. At the time of our fourth quarter earnings call in March, we provided a significant amount of detail to help you build your models. Looking forward, we continue to expect top line sales for 2014 to increase 8% to 9%. Overall square footage is expected to grow about 6% to 7%, and same-store sales are expected to increase 3% to 4%. While there may be some puts and takes in our operating performance, we are managing the business for the long-term benefit of the company and its shareholders. We continue to expect diluted earnings per share for the year of $3.45 to $3.55. 
We're committed to maintaining our investment-grade rating while managing to a leverage ratio of approximately 3x adjusted debt to EBITDA. This quarter, we temporarily increased our debt levels based on our share repurchases in the quarter. We're anticipating that we will repurchase $1.1 billion of our common stock this fiscal year. This includes the $800 million of share repurchases completed in the first quarter. For the year, we plan to open approximately 700 new stores, and capital expenditures are expected to be in the range of $450 million to $500 million. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Rick.

Thanks, David. I was pleased to see our overall business trends improve as the quarter progressed, and we are well positioned to achieve our 2014 objectives as we enter the second quarter. We remain focused on executing our top priorities -- top initiatives supporting our operating priorities in 2014. My goal is to share some of the insights into how we are thinking about sales and initiatives that support the projected acceleration of comp sales. 
First, as many of you have consistently heard from me, our disciplined category management is the foundation for our limited assortment offering and staying relevant to our customer. Today, more than ever, given the economic environment that has lingered for quite some time, affordability has now become the focus of our core customer. What affordability means to our customer today is the trade-off between price and quality that best fits her budget. At times, she is showing a greater willingness to compromise on quality or functionality to get a lower price point to stretch her money. We will never lose sight of our core customer and the trust that she places in us to help her stretch her household budget. In the first quarter alone, 49 planograms have been changed to provide more affordable items on our shelf across about 90% of our departments, making it easier for our customer not only to see great value but also to see affordability. 
We are leveraging the Smart & Simple private brand. Smart & Simple is a great platform that allows us to offer the lowest opening price points in categories on the shelf. The Smart & Simple brand was launched about 6 years ago to deliver affordability. Our customer recognizes that the brand is just as the name indicates and does not expect the product to be a national brand equivalent like our portfolio of other private brands, including Clover Valley, DG Health and DG Home. 
Smart & Simple allows us to further expand our product offerings and offer a good product at an opening price point that delivers affordability. This year alone, we will add approximately 40 new Smart & Simple products primarily across food, paper and home cleaning, including items from liquid dish soap to macaroni and cheese. This is complemented by SKU additions in key consumable categories such as food, home cleaning and paper products that are, again, focused on affordability. This includes new items that are a combination of national brands and our private brands. Given our customer's search for affordability, we have placed a renewed focus on the sweet spot for our customer across these important categories. Also, we expect to comp positive in tobacco for the year based on our customers' shopping patterns for this item. 
Pet food and related products is an important category for our customers. To capitalize on this trend, we implemented a new planogram with a better flow and brand-blocking. At the same time, we have a soft launch that is a complete re-branding of our private brand pet offerings, again, with a focus on opening price points and affordability. The planogram has completely -- has a completely new look and a new feel. We're already seeing some positive sales results as a result of this chain as it rolls out across the organization. 
We have also significantly increased the SKU assortment in the $1 to $5 price points across our non-consumable categories, including seasonal, home decor, stationery, accessories and shoes. We are not waiting on the economy to improve for our core customer as she continues to face headwinds in cost increases. Rather, we are sharpening our price points, and we expect our diligent work across categories to pay off as we move through the year. Our business is about continuous improvement. 
We are also committed as ever to our philosophy of everyday low price to drive traffic in units. Our customers trust our pricing, and we are committed to our brand promise of save time, save money every day. In the current promotional environment, we have begun recently and will continue to selectively and strategically invest in price in key products -- product categories that are sensitive to our customers to reinforce our value message. However, in line with the trust placed in us by our customers, these promotional activities will not be at the expense of EDLP. 
Later in the year, we will launch a DG digital coupon platform to accept digital-manufactured coupons and capitalize on this growing trend in retail. We have partnered with Coupons.com, the leader in digital promotions. Using this platform, we will be able to deliver individualized content such as national-manufacturer coupons and DG-exclusive offers to participating customers with the goal to drive trips and basket size. For our customers, the DG digital coupon program is flexible, personal and most importantly, incredibly easy to use. Our pilot to 1,000 stores rolls out in the next few weeks, with the national launch scheduled for completion by October. Over time, we believe this exciting program will drive shopper engagement. 
Turning to expense control. We are eliminating work that is non-value-added across every function in Dollar General, with a concentration on our retail operations. Improving efficiencies in our stores has been and will continue to be a significant priority for Dollar General. This is a two-pronged, cross-functional initiative to create time savings that we can reinvest to better manage our stores and service our customers. First, we are removing non-value-added work, and second, we are continuing to eliminate and streamline processes and activities in our stores. We expect these changes to allow our store managers and their teams to enhance their customer service efforts. For example, we have utilized technology to improve our tobacco ordering process and to better facilitate various personnel actions performed by our store managers, both of which provide time savings and improve our visibility to and control around these processes. 
The most significant ongoing work simplification effort relates to our store stocking process. During the fourth quarter of 2013, we rolled out the sorting of our rolltainers in the distribution centers by planogram to eliminate resorting at the stores and to reduce the number of steps or moves required to stock the shelves. We are now rolling out a rolltainer sort that separates promotional merchandise from core merchandise to produce efficiencies in setting promotional planograms and end caps. Throughout the year, we will have several incremental technology improvements that will help our store managers and their teams close the store faster each evening and streamline store reporting of key financial and operational information. 
As I mentioned earlier, we are focused on continuous improvement. As such, we are steadfastly committed to improving shrink and to utilizing the store-by-store optimized shrink level targets developed using applied predictive technology. We know we have a significant room to reduce our inventory shrink on a store-by-store basis, utilizing specific data for each store. This granular approach to controlling and reducing shrink provides us with the ability to prioritize areas for improvement. 
Enhancing our customer satisfaction program is another great example of Dollar General's dedication to continuous improvement. Earlier this year, we revamped our program with more actional items directly correlated to store standards in stock and the checkout experience. These new metrics give us a better view on what our customers want and value in our stores. We expect this program to benefit our customers' shopping experience and help drive sales. 
A true hallmark of the strength of Dollar General is our real estate processes for new stores, relocations and remodels. We are highly analytical, with a focus on driving returns. We're very pleased with the results of our new stores remodels and relocations over the past several years. We've continued to evolve our traditional Dollar General store and make this small-box model even more relevant. In 2015, we'll enter 3 new states as we introduce the traditional Dollar General store concept into Oregon, Maine and Rhode Island. These states have many communities where the Dollar General brand will resonate over time. 
We currently have approximately 1,400 of our traditional stores in the new DG13 format, which is more -- which is a more convenient layout, improved store stock signage and refreshed yellow and black color scheme. This design is delivering a comp lift above what we've seen with our previous remodels. Importantly, our customers are excited about the fresh look and shopability of this new layout. 
We continue to refine our Dollar General Plus model, which is similar to our traditional store but with wider aisles, increased shelf holding power and significantly expanded coolers. The Dollar General Plus format works very well as a replacement for an existing traditional store, where customers already know and trust Dollar General and where there's also a demand for expanded refrigerated food offerings. We will add about 100 Dollar General Plus stores to our fleet this year, primarily as a tool for relocations, as the returns are in line with the returns on a traditional Dollar General store. 
And finally, we're continuing to test new ideas in our Dollar General Market concept. 2014 will be another year of test-and-learn for this concept for the existing base, with 5 to 6 new stores being added, as we focus on driving sales, operating profit and returns. At the end of the first quarter, we had 11,338 stores with 83.6 million square feet of selling space in 40 states. 
Last year, we upgraded our site selection technology in order to fine-tune the way we look at opportunities for growth and to help us better understand the long-term potential of our small-box store. Our new model estimated more than 14,000 additional opportunities for the industry, 40% higher than our previous estimate of 10,000. Importantly, while our new model estimates our opportunities across all urbanicities, the model identified the highest improvement in opportunities in small town and rural markets. This allows us to capitalize on our strong heritage of serving others in these types of high-return markets. 
We've expanded our test of our life cycle remodel program to build our brand position in the marketplace as there's an opportunity to maximize sales with significantly lower capital expenditures. The life cycle remodel test focuses on our legacy stores that are smaller-footprint stores under 6,500 square feet that have not been updated in more than 7 years. The life cycle remodel improves adjacencies and planogram layout, allowing for a store that's closer to the format of our traditional Dollar General that we are building today. 
Additionally, the number of coolers in these stores is also being increased by 4 to 5 cooler doors each or 1,600 to 2,000 incremental cooler doors in total this year. We plan to complete 400 of these life cycle remodels in 2014, of which we've already completed more than 160 since January. These stores are already driving comparable sales with a lower capital spending requirement than a traditional remodel. Over time, we believe we have a significant base of 2,000 to 3,000 stores eligible for a life cycle remodel. 
The sales and returns on our new stores, relocations and remodels are strong, and we believe that reinvesting in our business through store growth remains the best use of our capital. In 2014, we are ahead of schedule to open approximately 700 new stores and to relocate or remodel approximately 500 stores in addition to the 400 life cycle remodels, resulting in square footage growth of 6% to 7%. 
To wrap up, we've started the second quarter with momentum. Our inventories are in good shape. Our balance sheet and cash flows are strong, and we are on track to distribute over $1 billion to our shareholders through the share repurchases in 2014. We have significant organic new store growth opportunities ahead that are high-return and play to our strength as we have built organizational capacities in our real estate function over time. I remain excited about the long-term opportunities ahead for Dollar General. My gratitude goes out to more than 103,000 Dollar General employees for all they do to fulfill our mission of serving others. 
With that, Mary Winn, I'd be glad to open up the lines for questions.

These stores are already driving comparable sales with a lower capital spending requirement than a traditional remodel. Over time, we believe we have a significant base of 2,000 to 3,000 stores eligible for a life cycle remodel. 
The sales and returns on our new stores, relocations and remodels are strong, and we believe that reinvesting in our business through store growth remains the best use of our capital. In 2014, we are ahead of schedule to open approximately 700 new stores and to relocate or remodel approximately 500 stores in addition to the 400 life cycle remodels, resulting in square footage growth of 6% to 7%.

I remain excited about the long-term opportunities ahead for Dollar General. Like do you see a range of -- are people buying different things? Are there just any subtle differences that you can share with us just to get a better sense of where the customer is at?

---

Joe, this is one of the most interesting businesses I have ever dealt with in that the SKU base is so limited and so narrow and so relevant that it pretty much -- it's pretty even just about everywhere, regardless of the demographic. And that's why we've been so successful, with every region in the United States historically trends positive because the model is so basic.

---

All right, operator, that -- I think, Brandi, that will conclude our call at this point. Thank you, everyone, for joining us. I know we left a few people in the queue, so please feel free to give me a call today or Emma Joe a call. And we look forward to updating you as we move through the year.
